questions.text: Which of the following can cause priapism?

A police officer presents an X-ray of a suspect who is believed to be a body packer. Patient acts casual and his vitals are stable The X-ray is as given. What is the most critical initial management step for this patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. Monitor and provide supportive care
questions.explanation:
Introduction
  • People who illegally carry narcotic drugs (Cocaine/Heroin), either by swallowing or insertion in the vagina/rectum as sealed pellets/packages.

Complications
  • GI obstruction/hemorrhage (caused by packets)
  • Packet rupture - Narcotic intoxication

Imaging
  • Abdominal X-ray (first-line)
  • Ultrasound or CT Scan (if unclear)

Management

Asymptomatic Patient:

  • Whole Bowel Irrigation (caution: potential rupture)
  • Alternatives: Allow packages to move into the colon Administer Enemas (Low-Volume Phospho Soda Enemas/ High-Volume Saline Enemas)
  • Avoid Food Ingestion: Until all packages are passed.
  • Encouraging Gastric Emptying :Metoclopramide 10 mg, 8-hourly

Symptomatic Patient:

  • Continuous-infusion of Naloxone
  • Whole bowel irrigation.
  • Surgical intervention may be required.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after taking an overdose of morphine. He is unresponsive with a respiratory rate of 6 breaths per minute. Which laboratory finding would you expect in this patient?

A 24 year old female was brought to the emergency department in comatose state and on examination, the vitals were BP:80/40, HR:42/min, RR:8/min, Temperature 36 degree, Reflexes: sluggish, Miosis with conjunctival congestion, spO2:85%. Multiple skin scars were noted on her left forearm.The attenders gave a history of the frequent domestic strife and mood swings following which she would have a long unexplained absence from home. The duty doctor suspected drug abuse and started appropriate management. Which among the following chemical tests can be used for diagnosis in this case?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Symptoms/Characteristics

Stage of Excitement

Short duration,Euphoria

Hallucinations,tachycardia

Flushing of face,Conjunctival injection

Stage of Stupor

Headache,nausea,vomiting

Weakness,heaviness in limbs

Dizziness, miosis,cyanosis of face and lips

Stage of Narcosis/Coma

Deep coma (unarousable)

Flaccid, relaxed muscles

Pale face, Absent reflexes

Congested conjunctiva

Cold skin with profuse perspiration

Pinpoint, non-reactive pupils

Hypotension, Weak, feeble pulse, Hypothermia, Bradypnoea

questions.text: All among the following are true regarding the image except:

options.label: A
options.text: Obtained from a plant called Paper somniferum

options.label: B
options.text: Extracted via vertical incision from unripe poppy

options.label: C
options.text: Addictive potential is due to its action on Kappa (κ) receptors

options.label: D
options.text: Pruritus is a common adverse effect

questions.correct_answer: C. Addictive potential is due to its action on Kappa (κ) receptors
questions.explanation:
Introduction
  • Dried extract from the poppy plant (Papaver somniferum)

Extraction
  • Obtained by vertical incisions from unripe poppy capsule (toxic part)

Toxic principles
  • Phenanthrene group: Morphine, Codeine and Thebaine
  • Benzylisoquinoline group: Papaverine and Noscapine

Mechanism of action (MOA)
  • Exhibits action via 3 receptors mainly - Mu(μ), Delta(δ) and Kappa(κ) receptors and release Endorphins.
  • Addictive potential is due to its action on Mu(μ) and Delta(δ) receptors
  • Action on Kappa(κ) receptor causes dysphoria - no addictive potential

Effects
  • Tolerability, Addiction, Dysphoria (κ-receptor)
  • Pruritus is a common adverse effect.
  • Other effects: Constipation, Respiratory depression, Urinary retention.
  • Tolerability is developed for all actions except: 3 Cs
    • Constipation
    • Convulsions
    • Constriction of pupils (Miosis)

Fatal dose

Opium: 2 g

Morphine: 0.2 g

Codeine: 80 mg

Fatal period: 6-12 hours

Management

  • Support vitals: Use a respirator and other emergency procedures.
  • Decontamination:
    • Stomach wash with 1:5000 KMnO₄, leaving some solution in the stomach to oxidize any secreted alkaloid.
    • Perform lavage even after IV/IM drug injection, as it is secreted in the stomach.
    • Administer activated charcoal as the primary decontamination method.
    • Enema with sodium sulfate twice daily.
    • Whole-bowel irrigation for body packers.
  • Antidote:
    • Naloxone

questions.text: Patient was brought to ED after being bitten by a snake as shown below. Which of the following steps are part of management in this patient? 1) Immobilize the limb by applying crepe bandages 2) Cauterize the bite wound 3) No test dose to be given before starting ASV 4) Dose of ASV should be halved in children 5) ASV given until clotting time becomes normal
questions.explanation:
First Aid: ‘ CARRY NO RIGHT ’

CARRY
  • Do not allow the victim to walk on their own, must be carried (in any form) to the hospital as soon as possible.

NO
  • No Suction
  • No Cautery
  • No Ligature
  • No Tourniquet

RIGHT
  • R: Reassure the patient
  • I: Immobilize the limb: by application of crepe bandages (Sutherland wraps)
  • GH: Get to the Hospital immediately
  • T: Tell history/symptoms

Pressure bandage
  • Used for immobilization of the limb by application of crepe bandage - known as Sutherland wraps.
  • Contraindicated in viper bites.
  • Ideal pressure: 50-70 mm Hg.

ASV
  • Mainstay of treatment.
  • Used only when signs of systemic poisoning are present
  • Polyvalent anti snake venom (PAV) used in India can neutralize (i) Cobra (ii) Krait (iii) Russel viper (iv) Saw-scaled viper bites.
  • Dose: 1-2 ml/kg (!0 vials) irrespective of sex/age.
  • Each vial: neutralizes 6-8 mg of snake venom
  • Test dose is not required/advised to be given before initiating ASV.
  • Ideally to be given within 4 hours of snake bite.
  • To be given until clinical improvement (in cobra bites)/ Clotting time becomes normal (in viper bites).

Adjuvant treatment
  • Neostigmine 1.5mg: for neuroparalytic symptoms (cobra bite).
  • Atropine 0.5mg: To antagonize muscarinic actions of Ach.
  • Surgical debridement and FFP may be required in Viper bites.

questions.text: Which of the following snakes is known for its myotoxic venom?
questions.explanation:
Neurotoxic Test

Vasculotoxic Test

Single Breath Count Test

  • Count numbers in a single breath.
  • Repeat the counting test every 15 minutes.
  • If it decreases, it indicates ongoing respiratory failure.

Whole Blood Clotting Test (WBCT)

  • Put whole blood in a clean and dry test tube.
  • Wait for 20 minutes and analyse the blood in the test tube.
  • After 20 minutes if blood clots: No snake bite or not vasculotoxic venom.
  • After 20 minutes if blood does not clot: Suggests Viper snake poisoning.

questions.text: Which of the following is a key difference between neurotoxic and vasculotoxic snake venoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Neurotoxic venom local reaction is extensive and vasculotoxic venom local reaction is minimal

options.label: B
options.text: Tongue paralysis is seen in vasculotoxic snakes.

options.label: C
options.text: Neurotoxic venom leads to severe swelling at the bite site, while vasculotoxic venom causes respiratory paralysis.

options.label: D
options.text: Neurotoxic venom causes wet gangrene , while vasculotoxic venom causes dry gangrene.

questions.correct_answer: D. Neurotoxic venom causes wet gangrene , while vasculotoxic venom causes dry gangrene.
questions.explanation:
Neurotoxic snakes (Elapidae)

Vasculotoxic (Viper)

Causes muscular, weakness of legs and paralysis of muscles of face, throat and respiration.

Causes enzymatic destruction of cell walls and coagulation disorders causing hemolysis.

Ptosis: B/L drooping of eyelid -M/C

DIC - Disseminated Intravascular Coagulopathy causing renal failure.

Local reaction: Minimal (Option A)

Local reaction: Extensive

Tongue paralysis seen (Option B)

Tongue not affected

Descending paralysis, Respiratory paralysis with dysphagia, dysphonia and dysarthria. (Option C)

Circulatory failure

Wet gangrene, early onset (Option D)

Dry gangrene, late onset

Pulse: Initially normal, then irregular.

Pulse: weak and irregular

Coagulation not affected

Coagulation with hemorrhagic manifestations

Normal pupils

Pupils dilated

Hypersalivation

Normal salivation

Staggering gait

Not affected specifically

questions.text: Which of the following is not a physical feature of a poisonous snake?
questions.explanation:
Poisonous snakes

Non-poisonous snakes

  • Head scales: Small, large scales seen with heat sensing pit antero-inferior to the eye.
  • Head scales: Large with certain exceptions.
  • Belly scales: Large and cover the entire breadth of belly.
  • Belly scales: Small like those on the back and do not cover the entire breadth.
  • Fangs: Long and canalized like a hypodermic needle.
  • Fangs: Short and solid.
  • Single row of scales.
  • Double rows of scales.
  • Tail compressed
  • Tail not markedly compressed.
  • Bite marks: Two fang marks, with or without small marks of other teeth.
  • Bite marks: Number of small teeth marks in row.

Snakes

Features and fatal doses

Common cobra
  • Head and neck: Hood present with spectacle marks
  • Belly: Smooth scales
  • Back: Spectacled white or yellow
  • Colour: Brown/black/green
  • Neurotoxic: Elapids
  • Fatal dose(Dried form)= 15mg

King cobra
  • Head and neck: Hood present without spectacle marks
  • Belly: Scales look shiny but dry to touch.
  • Back: Yellow or black bands with broad chevron like markings.
  • Colour: Yellow/black/green with white cross bands.
  • Neurotoxic: Elapids
  • Fatal dose(Dried form)= 12mg

Common krait
  • Head and neck: Covered with large shields.
  • Belly: Creamy white
  • Back: Single/double white bands with central row of hexagonal scales.
  • Colour: Steel blue/black.
  • Neurotoxic: Elapids
  • Fatal dose(Dried form)= 2-5-6mg

Banded krait
  • Head and neck: Covered with large shields.
  • Belly: Triangular in cross section.
  • Back: Alternate black and yellowish bands.
  • Colour: Steel blue/black.
  • Neurotoxic: Elapids
  • Fatal dose(Dried form)= 10 mg

Russell’s viper
  • Head and neck: Flat triangular with distinct ‘V’ mark and small scales.
  • Belly: White with broad plates.
  • Back: Three rows of diamond shaped black spots.
  • Colour: Brown/buff
  • Vasculotoxic
  • Fatal dose(Dried form)= 40 mg

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for the sting of the organism given below?
What is the mechanism of action of the poison found in these seeds (image)?

options.label: A
options.text: Stimulation of anterior horn cells of spinal cord

options.label: B
options.text: Inhibition of anterior horn cells of spinal cord

options.label: C
options.text: Stimulation of posterior horn of spinal cord

options.label: D
options.text: Inhibition of posterior horn of spinal cord

questions.correct_answer: A. Stimulation of anterior horn cells of spinal cord
questions.explanation:
Source

Seeds of Strychnos nux-vomica and other species of Strychnos plants found in India.

Mechanism of action

  • Stimulates all parts of the central nervous system, especially the anterior horn cells. Greatly increases reflex excitability by removing normal inhibition of motor cell stimulation, causing widespread uncontrolled motor activity of the spinal cord (Option A)
  • Slight stimuli like noise, light, or a breeze can cause violent generalized muscle spasms

Differentiating Points

Strychnine Poisoning

Tetanus

1. History

History of poisoning

History of injury

2. Onset

Sudden onset

Gradual onset

3. Convulsions/Spasms

Generalized convulsions

Lockjaw (trismus)

4. Chest Movement

Chest fixed during convulsions

Not typically fixed

5. Relaxation Between Spasms

Complete relaxation between seizures

Relaxation between spasms is never complete

6. Duration Until Fatality

Ends fatally within a few hours

Death is rare within a few hours

7. Chemical Evidence

Chemical analysis reveals the poison

No specific chemical detection

questions.text: A forensic pathologist is conducting an autopsy on a 38-year-old male who died after an accidental exposure to hydrofluoric acid (HF) at an industrial plant. Which of the following postmortem findings is most characteristic of HF poisoning?

options.label: C
options.text: Severe hypocalcemia and calcium deposits in tissues

questions.correct_answer: C. Severe hypocalcemia and calcium deposits in tissues
questions.explanation:
Hydrofluoric Acid (HF)

Chemical Properties
  • Aqueous solution of hydrogen fluoride (HF) in concentrations from 0.5% (domestic) to 100% (industrial).
  • Potent dehydrating agent; causes chemical burns.

Sources and Uses
  • Found in rust removers, detergents, cleaning agents.
  • Used in glass etching, metal processing, fluorine compound production.

Mechanism of Toxicity
  • Corrosive: Hydrogen ions cause immediate tissue damage by coagulative necrosis.
  • Fluoride ion toxicity: Fluoride ions penetrate tissues, leading to liquefactive necrosis and systemic toxicity.

Routes of Exposure
  • Dermal contact: Common, causes severe burns.
  • Inhalation: Leads to respiratory distress.
  • Ingestion: Causes gastrointestinal burns.

Symptoms
  • Dermal burns: Severe pain, redness, necrosis (may be delayed).
  • Ocular injury: Conjunctivitis, corneal erosion, possible vision loss.
  • Respiratory issues: Coughing, dyspnea, pulmonary edema (from inhalation).
  • Gastrointestinal distress: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain (from ingestion).
  • Neuromuscular: Confusion, seizures due to electrolyte imbalances (hypocalcemia, hyperkalemia).

Autopsy Findings
  • Severe burns in esophageal and gastric mucosa.
  • Hyperemic lesions in the renal tubular system.
  • Necrotic lesions in cardiac muscle.

Management

  • Promptly rinse the area with water or saline for at least 30 minutes.
  • Apply 2.5% calcium gluconate gel every 10-15 minutes until pain subsides.
  • Severe cases may require intravenous calcium gluconate, airway support, and monitoring of electrolytes in an ICU setting.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is found unconscious with a strong odor of antiseptic on his breath. He is rushed to the emergency department where he develops hypotension and renal failure. On examination, his angle of mouth is stained gray, and he has burns on his esophagus. The patient had a history of greenish discoloration of urine. What is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.explanation:
Phenol Poisoning (Carbolism)

Physical Properties

Colorless, crystalline, turns pink on air exposure; slightly acidic, forms phenolate ion (C6H5O⁻).

Uses

Antiseptic/disinfectant; Lysol (50% cresol), Dettol (chlorinated phenol with turpineol).

Fatal Dose

1-2 g phenol or 25-50 ml of household phenol.

Fatal Period

3-4 hours.

Tissue Discoloration

Can lead to ochronosis (bluish-black discoloration in tissues like ears and sclera).

Signs and symptoms
  • Local Effects: Tingling → numbness → coagulation necrosis → painless white eschar, which turns brown and sloughs off.
  • Gastrointestinal: Initial burning/tingling, later anesthesia; diarrhea and abdominal pain, vomiting rare.
  • Respiratory: Phenol odor on breath, laryngeal/pulmonary edema, stertorous breathing, cyanosis.
  • Metabolized by kidneys into hydroquinone/pyrocatechol; causes carboluria (dark green urine).
  • Cardiovascular (CVS): Rapid, feeble, irregular pulse; cold, clammy skin; collapse, unconsciousness, coma.
  • Muscular: Muscle spasms, convulsions
  • CNS: Headache, giddiness, tinnitus, contracted pupils.
  • Renal: Dark smoky green color of urine.

Postmortem Findings
  • External: Gray/brown corrosions on mouth, body, hands; phenolic odor, delayed putrefaction.
  • Internal: Corroded GIT mucosa, leathery stomach, pulmonary edema, hemorrhagic nephritis.

Medico-legal Aspects

Used in suicides, accidental poisoning, rare for homicides (strong odor/taste), abortifacient.

questions.text: A forensic pathologist is performing autopsies on two individuals who died from chemical poisoning. One case involves nitric acid and the other oxalic acid. Which of the following postmortem findings is most consistent with oxalic acid poisoning rather than nitric acid poisoning?

options.label: A
options.text: Yellow discoloration of the skin with congestion of the larynx and trachea

options.label: C
options.text: Soft, friable stomach wall with ulceration

options.label: D
options.text: Gelatinous brown stomach content with swollen, congested kidneys showing necrosis

questions.correct_answer: D. Gelatinous brown stomach content with swollen, congested kidneys showing necrosis
questions.explanation:
Feature

HNO₃ (Nitric Acid)

Oxalic Acid

Physical Properties

Colorless, pungent, choking, burning taste, fuming

Colorless, transparent, prismatic crystals, resembles MgSO₄ and ZnSO₄

Fatal Dose

10–15 ml

15–20 g

Fatal Period

12–24 hours

1–2 hours (may extend to 2 days–2 weeks with renal failure)

Signs and Symptoms
  • Oropharyngeal burns, pain in throat and epigastrium
  • Dysphagia, dyspnea, dysphonia
  • Eructation, vomiting
  • Thirst
  • Fulminating: Immediate symptoms, coffee-ground vomiting, severe thirst, diarrhea, electrolyte imbalance, death within minutes
  • Acute: Tingling, numbness, tetany, convulsions, renal failure
  • Delayed: Nephritis, oxaluria, renal failure

Vomitus

Acidic, contains altered blood and mucous

Coffee-ground vomitus

Teeth

Yellowish coating, not brittle

No specific change

Urination & Tenesmus

Present

Renal failure, scanty urine, oxaluria

Abdominal Findings
  • Abdominal distension due to gas
  • Tenderness
  • Stiffness (due to distension)

Burning pain, abdominal distension

Skin and Mucosa Erosion

Yellow discoloration over angles of mouth, lips, fingers
  • No external findings
  • Mucosal bleaching, corrosion in mouth, esophagus, stomach

Perforation of Stomach

Less common

No perforation, gelatinous brown content in stomach (Option D) (Option B ruled out)

Postmortem Findings

(Option A and D ruled out)
  • Yellow discoloration of skin
  • Congestion of larynx, trachea
  • Soft, friable stomach wall, ulcerated
  • Bleached mucosa (mouth, pharynx, esophagus)
  • Red, velvety or blackish stomach wall
  • Swollen, congested kidneys with necrosis

Medico-Legal Aspects

Accidental or suicidal, homicide rare

Usually accidental (mistaken for MgSO₄), rare in suicides or homicides, occasionally used as an abortifacient

questions.text: A 40 year old man was found unconscious at home, with an open container of unknown acid nearby. He was rushed to the ER but died shortly after arrival. During autopsy, the police surgeon notes several injuries consistent with corrosive ingestion along with chalky white, brittleteeth. Which forensic finding would solidify the above finding in this case?

options.label: B
options.text: Blackish staining and necrosis of the lips and mouth

options.label: D
options.text: Yellowish staining and necrosis of the lips and mouth

questions.correct_answer: B. Blackish staining and necrosis of the lips and mouth
questions.explanation:
Sulfuric Acid (H₂SO₄)
  • Physical Properties:
    • Colorless, odorless, with a burning taste; oily and non-fuming.
  • Fatal Dose: 5–10 ml of concentrated acid.
  • Fatal Period: 12–18 hours post-ingestion.

Signs and Symptoms
  • Burning sensation and pain in the throat and epigastric region.
  • Dysphagia, dyspnea, dysphonia
  • Eructation and vomiting: Frequent belching and vomiting.
  • Thirst: Present (worsened vomiting by drinking fluids)
  • Vomitus: Strongly acidic, contains altered blood and mucous shreds.
  • Teeth: Become chalky white and brittle.
  • Constipation: Usually present.
  • Urination: Suppressed.
  • Tenesmus present
  • Nature of stool: Presence of mucus and altered blood.
  • Tenderness over the abdomen
  • Abdominal stiffness due to peritonitis
  • Abdominal distension: Uncommon.
  • Skin and mucous membrane erosion: Especially on the mouth, lips, and fingers; blackening and excoriation occur.
  • Stomach Perforation: Frequently seen.

Cause of Death
  • Shock, stomach perforation, peritonitis, laryngeal spasm, and malnutrition from esophageal stricture.

Postmortem Findings
  • Erosion of skin and mouth angles, black charring of the stomach, stomach perforation, and swelling in the liver and kidneys.

 

Perforation of stomach

  

 

Thinning of posterior wall of the stomach

Medico-Legal Aspects
  • Often occurs accidentally (mistaken for glycerin) or in suicide cases.
  • Rarely associated with homicide.
  • May be used as an abortifacient or for vitriolage (acid attacks).

questions.text: In cases of poisoning by corrosive substances, gastric lavage can be performed in which of the following situations? A) Sulphuric acid poisoning B) Hydrochloric acid poisoning C) Carbolic acid (Phenol) poisoning D) Ammonia poisoning E) Oxalic acid poisoning
questions.correct_answer: B. All except A and B
questions.explanation:
Type of Poison

Management

Mineral Acids

(Sulphuric acid, Nitric acid, Hydrochloric acid)
  • Avoid gastric lavage/emetics.
  • Dilute by giving milk or water.
  • Administer 4 tablespoons of aluminum hydroxide gel.
  • Provide demulcents (olive oil, milk, egg white, starch water, butter).
  • Avoid bicarbonate or neutralizing agents.
  • Prednisolone: 60 mg/day in divided doses.
  • Treat shock with IV fluids, blood products (if bleeding), and antibiotics (if perforation is suspected).
  • Tracheostomy for glottic edema.
  • Nothing by mouth for a week, followed by IV nutrients, gradually reintroducing liquids, soft foods, and regular diet.
  • Morphine for pain relief.
  • Symptomatic treatment.

Organic Acids

Oxalic Acid

  • Gastric lavage with calcium lactate (2 tsp/lavage).
  • Antidotes: Limewater, calcium lactate, calcium gluconate/chloride (150 mg/kg orally) to form insoluble calcium oxalate for excretion.
  • Calcium gluconate: 10 ml of 10% solution IV frequently.
  • Parathyroid extracts: 100 units IM.
  • Bowel management: Demulcent drinks, enemas, purgatives.
  • Hemodialysis/exchange transfusion if needed.
  • Symptomatic treatment.

Carbolic Acid (Phenol)

  • Gastric lavage (done with caution) with lukewarm water, charcoal, olive oil, MgSO4, or Na2SO4.
  • Leave medicinal liquid paraffin or 30 g MgSO4 in the stomach after lavage.
  • Provide demulcents.
  • IV saline with 7 g NaHCO3/l to manage circulatory depression, dilute carbolic acid and promote diuresis.
  • If phenol contacts the skin: Remove contaminated clothing, wash with soap and water, and apply olive oil/methylated spirit.
  • Emetics have a limited role.

Alkalis
  • Gastric lavage/emetics contraindicated.
  • Immediately dilute with water.
  • Give demulcents (egg white, milk).
  • Administer O2 inhalation in case of ammonia vapor poisoning
  • Maintain airway, tracheostomy if needed.
  • Administer parenteral analgesics and antibiotics.
  • Steroids contraindicated if esophageal perforation is present.

Corrosives Classification

Acids

  

Alkalis

Mineral acids

Organic acids

Example:

  • Sulphuric acid
  • Nitric acid
  • Hydrochloric acid

Example:

  • Oxalic acid
  • Carbolic acid
  • Acetic acid
  • Salicylic acid

Example:

  • Caustic potash and soda
  • Ammonium hydroxide

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of the toxin present in this plant?
questions.explanation:
Source

Roots, leaves, and seeds contain several glycosides: digitoxin, digitalin, digitalein, and digitonin (most poisonous).

Mechanism of action
  • Glycosides act on the heart, improving heart function by prolonging the diastolic period.
  • In toxic doses, they increase excitability and cause extrasystoles.

Treatment
  • ECG monitoring.
  • Gastric lavage with tannic acid solution.
  • Activated charcoal.
  • Purgatives if needed.
  • Atropine for bradycardia.
  • Potassium chloride to reduce extrasystoles.
  • Lignocaine, novocaine, or propranolol for cardiac arrhythmias.
  • Trisodium EDTA may help lower serum calcium.
  • Symptomatic treatment.

questions.text: Given is the image of a poisonous plant. Which part of this plant is poisonous?
questions.explanation:
Source

All parts of the plant are poisonous. (Option B)

Active Principles
  • Glycosides: Thevetin, thevotoxin, cerberin, peruvoside.
  • Thevetin: A powerful cardiac poison.
  • Thevotoxin: Less toxic than thevetin, similar to digitalis glycosides.
  • Cerberin: Acts like strychnine.

Symptoms
  • Local: Sap may cause inflammation.
  • Ingestion: Burning sensation in the mouth, tingling of the tongue, dry throat, vomiting, diarrhea, headache, dizziness.
  • Later stages: Dilated pupils, drowsiness, loss of muscular power, rapid/weak/irregular pulse, falling blood pressure, heart block.
  • Death: Due to peripheral circulatory failure.

Treatment
  • Gastric lavage and single-dose activated charcoal.
  • IV sodium lactate molar solution and 5% glucose to combat acidosis.
  • Atropine, Adrenaline, and Noradrenaline to counteract heart block and low blood pressure.
  • Digoxin-specific antibody fragments to treat life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias.
  • Symptomatic treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following statements on aconite is false?

options.label: A
options.text: All parts of the plant are poisonous

questions.explanation:
Species

Aconitum napellus, Aconitum ferox

Synonyms

Monk’s hood, mitha zaher, bish, wolf’s bane, women’s bane, devil’s helmet, or blue rocket

Source
  • All parts of the plant are poisonous (Option A ruled out)
  • Root and root tubers are the most potent (often mistaken for horseradish root)

Active Principles

Aconitine, pseudo-aconitine, indaconitine, picraconitine, aconine.

Mechanism of Action

Affects voltage-sensitive sodium channels, stimulates then paralyzes sensory nerves, secretory nerves, CNS, and myocardium. (Option C ruled out)

Symptoms (by system)
  • GIT: Nausea, vomiting, salivation, abdominal pain, diarrhea, burning/tingling of mouth, tongue, throat, followed by numbness.
  • CVS: Hypotension, bradycardia, chest pain, ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation, slow/feeble pulse.
  • CNS: Vertigo, restlessness, headache, giddiness.
  • MS: Muscle weakness, twitching, spasms.
  • RS: Slow, labored, shallow breathing.
  • Ocular: Alternating pupil dilation/contraction (hippus), diplopia, impaired vision.
  • Others: Subnormal temperature, cold skin, yellow-green vision, tinnitus, paralysis of facial muscles.
  • Death: Respiratory failure or ventricular fibrillation.

Fatal Dose

Root: 1-2 g.(Option D ruled out)

Treatment
  • No specific antidote.
  • Gastric lavage with tannic acid/activated charcoal.
  • Inotropic therapy for hypotension, atropine for bradycardia.
  • Ventricular arrhythmia treated with amiodarone, flecainide; cardiopulmonary bypass for refractory cases.

Medico-legal Aspects
  • Ideal homicidal poison: cheap, easily available, small lethal dose, short fatal period, difficult to detect postmortem. (Option B)
  • Accidental poisoning: mistaken for horseradish

questions.text: Which of the following statements on strychnine poisoning is wrong?

options.label: C
options.text: Strychnine can be detected in putrefied bodies and viscera

options.label: D
options.text: Brain and spinal cord should be preserved for analysis

questions.correct_answer: A. Rigor mortis sets in late
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features
  • Opisthotonos- arched body with only the back of head and heels touching the ground:

  • Emprosthotonos- forward curve
  • Pleurothotonus- sideways curve
  • Risus sardonicus- fixed grin:

Treatment

- Immediate Care: Place in a dark, quiet room.

- Anesthesia: Chloroform or intravenous barbiturate if spasms allow.

- Adsorption: Administer animal charcoal to absorb free strychnine, or tannic acid if charcoal is unavailable.

- Antidotes: Intravenous barbiturates to stop convulsions.

- Muscle relaxants: Mephenesin, intravenous diazepam for anticonvulsant effects.

Autopsy Findings

- Rigor mortis: Sets in almost immediately (Option A) and passes off early.

- Stomach contents: Remains of seeds may be found.

- Delayed putrefaction. (Option B ruled out)

- Toxicological analysis: Strychnine can be detected in putrefied bodies and viscera (Option C ruled out); brain and spinal cord should be preserved for analysis. (Option D ruled out)
